pros: Nice facilities, flexible hours, diverse student body.
cons: Pay is NOT commensurate with experience. I have been there for over 10 years, yet I get paid the same as someone starting this year. "Senior Adjunct" title is a joke. Have to spend hours filling out forms, writing the application and being interviewed, all for a paltry $200 extra per semester. They keep adding administrative positions and not focusing on adding high quality full time faculty.

job_title: Clinical Nurse Educator in Phoenixville, PA
pros: 1. Students are well prepared for clinical. 2. Pay is better than some private universities (adjunct faculty position). 3. The full-time staff do an excellent job at ensuring that adjunct faculty have all necessary resources for clinical and are available to assist with any clinical concerns. 4. Students are rotated off the clinical floor for various experience. On average, an instructor may have 7 or 8 students total, but with the rotations there will be only 5 or 6 students on the clinical floor at a time.
cons: 1. Depending on the clinical site, sometimes it was difficult finding a place to hold post conference.

pros: The College is a great team environment whose ultimate goal is to help students succeed.
cons: We have had extensive turnover since the pandemic.

job_title: Associate Professor of English in Media, PA
pros: There are lots of on-the-ground people who care about student success.
cons: There's been so much leadership turnover in the last few years that the vision for the institution has been lost. So much of the time, leadership is focused on "what we can do to get back to where we were" (pre-pandemic) instead of committing to new ideas.

review_title: Highly Recommended Place to Work and Study
pros: Great place to work and learn! For the most part, with few exceptions, the administrators, faculty and staff are friendly and welcoming. Students often comment about the quality of the education they have received at the college. Salaries are competitive and parking for students, faculty, administrators and staff is plentiful. Many of the college's campuses have been reconstructed or improved, so the facilities are top notch.
cons: By and large, there are few "cons" about the college. Like any large organization, there is a level of bureaucracy that sometimes gets in the way of getting things done quickly and efficiently. However, a new work management system that was just implemented may help. As the college's student base becomes more ethnically diverse, it will need to do more to create a welcoming environment, including hiring more people of color and infusing diverse perspectives and courses into the curriculum. The year 2017 will prove very interesting because the college's president plans to retire, so a new president must be hired. And, once the new president takes over, she/he will set about hiring a new provost to replace the acting provost. The college also has several academic dean positions it must fill soon.

review_title: Great People, Great benefits, Nice place, but - Watch out for the politics.
pros:
The people. Your fellow co-workers are the salt of the earth. Very nice, down to earth people. They are very willing to assist you, and fun to be around.
The benefits are primo! Can't beat them, they are better than most schools. Employees only pay 3% toward their benefits. They also offer the PSEA retirement pension - don't pass it up if you get the chance. Also free tuition for employee and spouse and dependants. Tuition reimbursement for a 4 year degree or graduate degree.
Free parking, no city wage tax. Its great to be in an educational environment.
cons: The Politics. The good old boy network is alive and well here. Promotions are made by who you know. There is favoritism. Its hard to move up anywhere in the college, unless you are starting from a low level. But if you are mid level in job classification, its hard to get a job in a different department because everytime, you'll get a rejection letter that they hired someone with experience in that particular job. So how do you get experience if you can't move out of where you are? There isn't money to send employees to get job training either.

review_title: Why change things that were working well?
pros: I love and respect my department managers.  They work with me to fit their requirements of me into their schedule, and they are gracious about recognizing their employees' work.
cons: The college recently brought in a new HR director who changed the temporary employee policies.  Veteran department temps who have earned the privilege of choosing their shifts have been forced basically to reapply for their jobs.  Their hours are being given to new people who don't know the systems or procedures.  In the past, I could have counted on at least 20 hours per month--now I'm worried that I'll receive even 10 hours.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Kennett Square, PA
pros: Good opportunity to get experience when you are getting back into career after absence. I was a stay at home mom for more than 10 years, but I have a master's degree. I couldn't find work at most places since I had this gap. But they took a chance on me, and I found that I love teaching. They provide opportunity for growth through training and symposium.
cons: Mostly want part time adjunct faculty  - if you are looking for full time work it's more difficult to find employment.

pros: The college is pretty well organized
cons: Admins and full-time faculty do not always make the most intelligent decisions.  It's a community college, so students demonstrate a wide-range of abilities and personalities.  As an adjunct you are exploited- ie payed far less than full-time faculty, asked to cover other professors classes (at least the STEM Dean Schwartz routinely asks this of adjunct faculty).  Unless you are retired or looking to modestly supplement your income, I would stay away from adjuncting at DCCC as DCCC is a career dead-end.

review_title: The Ins and Outs of DCCC
pros: Great benefits and higher compensation than comparable positions at other schools.  Great if you like working with first-generation students.  231 hours of accrued personal and vacation time each year.  Free parking.  You're able to participate in interdisciplinary committees around the College that offer you exposure to other segments of the industry.
cons:
No merit based raises.
Not a lot of funds invested in professional development.
Personnel resources are being stretched.

review_title: A Nice Place to Work, but...
pros: Great people who care about their work and serving students; A real sense of community among the front line staff; Dedicated Professionals who know how to get the job done
cons: Morale often low due to low esteem; Many people feel their concerns are not heard and they fear for their jobs if they speak out

pros: It was an easy job. Pay was fine and my supervisor was nice.
cons: I had to work a lot with very unmotivated and unintelligent students. One student  came in and asked me for help without even knowing what homework  problem they wanted help with. Another student seemed kind of eager but made me go through every single homework problem with her and it was annoying. A lot of the students were like that.

review_title: I worked at DCCC for a year as a student assistant
